page.title: 01Farmland East of Bodmin Moor
page.content: This area around Lewannick village is predominantly dairy farmland. Farms average sixty to a hundred acres usually employing family labour or one or two local people. Crops are grassland for grazing, hay and silage with some barley for winter feeding. The land is open and hilly, a few wooded areas, steeper slopes on which beef cattle graze. Sheep also graze the rougher land. Stone walls and hedges enclose the fields giving protection from rough weather from Bodmin Moor. The old stone cottages and farmhouses, many recently renovated on a government grant, are interspersed with modern bungalows. A considerable number of cottages and bungalows are occupied by non-local retired people. The Anglican church, Methodist chapel, inn and village hall provide meeting places.
